Amendments Nos. 6 and 8 are related and may be discussed together.
I move amendment No. 6:
In page 9, subsection (2) (b), line 51, to delete “twenty-five years” and substitute “one year”.

Here we are talking about the purchase price which the householder will have to pay to get his freehold. There are basically two methods of assessing the amount to be paid by the householder. Where there are more than 25 years to run in the lease the householder will be entitled to purchase according to an automatic multiplier related to the most recent long term national loan. If he does not qualify to purchase under that heading he must then go to arbitration and obtain agreement on a figure. Here he can really run into trouble because of the items which are to be taken into account at such arbitration and the cost involved could be very high. The purpose of the amendment is to reduce the term from 25 years to one year. This has the support of the tenants' organisations. The effect of accepting the amendment would be that all those with more than one year to run on their lease would be entitled to purchase, taking advantage of the automatic multiplier.

MainHeading.P: The question that has occurred to me is why should one take a figure of 25 out of the air? If the object of the Bill is to encourage the purchase of ground rents, I believe there would be far more people purchasing in this category if they were able to take advantage of the automatic multiplier. That is the basis of my amendment, suggesting that all those with more than one year to run on their lease should be entitled to take advantage of the automatic multiplier costing rather than having this confined to those with 25 years or more to run.

The difficulty that would arise in particular with somebody not able to take advantage of such a situation is that the Bill provides that the arbitrator would have to bear in mind in assessing the sum payable the amount of rent which would be reserved by a reversionary lease. Anybody unfortunate enough to be in this situation would certainly bear in mind that the amount of rent payable under a reversionary lease where a lease is expiring could in many cases be perhaps 2,000 per cent greater than the rent already payable. Under the 1958 Act, as amended, the rent to be fixed on a reversionary lease is the current occupational rent divided by eight. You could have a case of an old ground rent. In fact, if a lease is expiring it is probably an old ground rent where the figure payable might be only £5 and the purchase costing under the automatic multiplier would not exceed £40 or £50. You could find that the amount of rent assessed on a reversionary lease could perhaps be some hundreds of pounds. The figure so assessed would have to be borne in mind by the arbitrator in fixing the purchase money.

I suggest, not as the total solution of the problem but as a way of improving the situation, that the entitlement to automatic purchase should be extended to all those with more than one year to run on their leases.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. G. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: The 25 years is the period that the lease has to run at the time the purchase price is being determined by arbitration. If the period is less, under subsection 2 (b) the arbitrator will have regard not only to the current rent but also to the notional rent on renewal. Similarly, under subsection (3) if the lease has less than 25 years to run the maximum purchase price formula will not apply. The concept that a lease which has expired or almost expired is more valuable to the landlord who is entitled to an increased rent on termination than a lease with many years to run was introduced in the 1967 Act following a very thorough examination by the Ground Rents Commission. This can be seen in their report in paragraphs 95 and 129. I accept that this is fair. The commission drew the line at 25 years and argued on the basis of the evidence received that when a lease has more than that period to run the landlord's prospect of an increased rent on termination should not be a factor in determining the price. Whatever argument might be made about the precise cut-off point, whether it might be 20, 25 or 30 years—although the question if raised would be one for determination by objective evidence rather than by opinion—there is no doubt that a cut off point of one year would certainly have a confiscatory effect so far as the landlord is concerned and, I might add, might be held to be unconstitutional. If the Deputy's amendment were accepted subsection (6) would have to be amended also because it is consequential on the concept of the 25 years to run. It provides that when a lease has less than 25 years to run the arbitrator will not ignore the maximum purchase price but will in effect apply it pro rata.

He will add to the maximum purchase price one-twenty-fifth of the difference between that price and a price paid on the reversionary rent for every year less than 25 years that the lease has to run. I think Deputy O'Keeffe will agree that the figure of 25 is not one that was, as he said, grasped out of the air; it was one that came up after very careful consideration by the commission, and as well as that it is in the 1967 Act.

It is very difficult to look forward 25 years and envisage what the reversionary rent would be, taking into account inflation and the changing values of money. This amendment was put down because we feel that the spirit of the Bill should be to give the most favourable terms possible to the lessee and to make it as attractive as we can for him to purchase the ground rent. While the Minister explained the figure of 25 years, it does seem to be looking a long way forward, certainly in so far as the person who would be considering purchasing his ground rent is concerned. While it may not in the Minister's view be possible to accede to all of this it may be possible to have some compromise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: This ground rents formula is laid down in the 1931 Act. It is to take one-eighth of the gross rent, and valuers do it every day of the week. I cannot see any difficulty as far as the arbitrator is concerned.

I have one point further to that raised by Deputy Mrs. Desmond. If the Minister cannot accept our joint amendment to bring it down to one year, can it be brought down to meet us to some extent? Would the Minister agree to look into it to see if the figure could be brought down?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: As I said to Deputy Mrs. Desmond, I have a very open mind on it. It is not the holy figure for me and I am prepared to ask the commission to have another look at it. Perhaps in the light of things as they are at present there might be an adjustment.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.
I move amendment No. 7:
In page 10, subsection (2), lines 17 to 21, to delete paragraph (g), and substitute the following new paragraphs:
“(g) the price paid by the lessor in purchasing the land and the amount of the site fine paid by the lessee,
(h) the number of years in which the rent has already been paid by the lessee,

MainHeading.P: (i) the costs and expenses, which have been incurred by the lessee due to the failure of the lessor to maintain any local amenities such as gardens, footpaths, playing spaces which he has covenated to do under the terms of the lease,
(j) the failure of the lessor to make any demand for payment of rent over a period of years.”.

There are two aspects to this amendment. Firstly, it proposes the deletion of section 17 (2) (g) and that clause as it stands requires the arbitrator, in fixing the amount to be paid of the purchase price of the ground rent, to take into account the costs and expenses which in the opinion of the arbitrator will be incurred by the landlord in investing the purchase money payable in respect of the acquisition of the fee simple. It appears that including such a provision really gives an open sesame to a landlord. In a way he has complete freedom to arrange his reinvestment of the proceeds in any manner or any place he wishes, and this is quite proper and correct. What he does with his money is his own business and not the householder's business.

It should not be the householder's business, but because of the inclusion of this clause it is very much the householder's business. The householder in the case of arbitration will be required to include in the purchase money the figure covering the costs and expenses of the landlord's reinvestment. This opens up all sorts of possibilities, bearing in mind that there does not appear to be a discretion here. The word used in the clause is “will”, so that it is not a question of the costs and expenses which may be reasonably incurred, or any words to that effect; it is a question of the costs and expenses which will be incurred. Think of the possibilities that might arise out of a shrewd use of that clause by an unscrupulous landlord. He could give evidence that he intended reinvesting the proceeds in a fishingboat venture in China, and if he gave evidence to that effect he would no doubt give evidence of the considerable expense in so doing, the necessity to get exchange control regulations, the necessity to get people to deal with the problem in China and probably the expense of going to China to look after the completion of his reinvestment. I accept that the example I am quoting is a little outrageous, but one has at times to be somewhat outrageous.

Speaker.P: It is more than a little, I think.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Would the Deputy not accept that the maximum purchase price puts the damper on any trip to China—say it is eight times the ground rent?

No, with respect, the Minister is on the wrong track there because the question of the cost or reinvestment would not arise were the automatic multiplier applied. It arises only where the automatic multiplier does not arise and we go to arbitration. It is one of the factors to be taken into account by the arbitrator, so that unfortunately in such a situation the trip to China could be on.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I am afraid it would be a very slow boat and we would be doing our own paddling. We would have no power.

We will not be encouraging all the landlords of the country to go on holidays to China. However, if a landlord were reinvesting the proceeds, say, in the national loan, no expense would be involved. Why then should we be, as it were, even encouraging the landlord to invest his moneys in other than the national loan? I accept that this provision was, as I recollect, in the 1967 Act, but I do not see the need for it. If the landlord gets his money it is up to him to do what he will with that money. There certainly should be no obligation on the householder or tenant to have to bear any expense at all in dealing with the landlord's arrangement for reinvestment of the proceeds.

MainHeading.P: This clause is couched in fairly strict terms. Even the word “reasonably” is not in it. It states that the arbitrator must take into account costs and expenses which will be incurred. For that reason I feel fairly strongly that the Minister should consider deleting this clause entirely. There seems to be no justification for it. If I cannot press my view totally on the Minister that he should delete it entirely, at least it should be modified.

There are other aspects to this amendment. I am suggesting that a number of subclauses be inserted which are not really related to this particular point. Do you want me to continue to deal with the subclauses which I suggest might be included or do you want us to dispose of this point first?

Speaker.P: I would ask the Deputy to dispose of the whole amendment at this stage. We take the full amendment.

That is probably the more proper procedure. We are talking about the clauses which an arbitrator has to bear in mind in assessing the purchase money to be paid by the householder in buying his freehold. There is a list of them in subsection (2).

I have dealt with the suggestion that clause (g) be deleted. The balance of the amendment covers a number of additional items which should be considered by the arbitrator in assessing the purchase price. These items have been suggested by ACRA and relate to the price paid by the landlord in purchasing land and the amount of the site fine paid by the lessee. If we accept this portion of the amendment it would mean that the arbitrator would investigate what had been paid by the landlord in the past for the property and in addition the site fine payable by the lessee or his predecessors in title.

MainHeading.P: One could have a situation where such an investigation might disclose that many years ago the landlord had paid £1,000 for a site—that would have been a lot of money 40 or 50 years ago. On that property over a period he might have built 50 or 60 houses and charged, on average, apart from ground rents, a site fine of £100 for the houses. If the investigation disclosed that type of information—and I have no doubt that many developments would disclose a similar type of situation—it would clearly show that the landlord had been amply compensated over the years for the amount he originally paid for the lands. The view of ACRA is that such a factor should be borne in mind by the arbitrator in fixing the purchase money. They do not suggest that because of such a situation there should be acquisition without compensation, in effect a confiscation. Their view is that this is a factor which should be borne in mind by the arbitrator and seems to be a reasonable viewpoint.

The second additional item we are suggesting should be included under this section is that the arbitrator should bear in mind in fixing the purchase money the number of years in which the rent has already been paid. I have no doubt that a householder whose father and grandfather have paid rent for their house for a 100 years would feel that that factor should be borne in mind in assessing the purchase price.

The third factor I am asking to have included is the cost and expenses which the householder may have to bear because of breach of covenant by the landlord. Whatever viewpoint the Minister might take in relation to the first two items, there can be no possible objection to accepting this provision or, if he accepts it in principle, to having the parliamentary draftsman frame it properly. This item should be included. If the landlord has got away with breach of covenant, that is the time to penalise him for it. “Penalise” is the wrong word because it is righting the balance between himself and the householder.

The last item under this amendment is that the arbitrator should take into account the failure of the landlord over a period of years to demand payment of that rent. If the Minister accepts this in principle, it would probably have to be drafted in more parliamentary language. The landlord must not care a great deal for his rights in his property if he has not bothered to collect his rents. He obviously does not have any interest in it and shows very little interest in his entitlement to the ground rents out of it.

The other inequity which could arise here is that arrears of rent may have been allowed to accumulate over a considerable period. The ground rent might be £30 which would not put the householder in severe difficulties when paying it in a year, but if he were considering purchasing the house the additional burden of paying very considerable arrears, maybe an extra couple of hundred pounds, might impose an intolerable burden. There could be a situation where this additional burden is put on the tenant when purchasing, solely because the landlord did not bother to collect his rent. This amendment proposes that this aspect should also be borne in mind in assessing the purchase price.

Speaker.P: The first part of our amendment calls for the deletion of sub-paragraph (g). When reading the Bill for the first time this appears to be outlandish. Deputy O'Keeffe made a case for its deletion and spoke about the possibilities which it could present for the landlords as being outlandish. I could say they were no more outlandish than the possibilities outlined by the Minister when speaking on the Bill in the House before the dissolution of the D·il. Whether the landlord goes to Canada or Australia, there is no need for us to convince the Minister of this. This is a matter which came to his notice and on which he dwelt at length when speaking in opposition to the Bill then before the House. This paragraph should be deleted.

MainHeading.P: With regard to our suggestions for the substitution of new paragraphs, the case can readily be made that from the lessee's point of view the site fine in many cases represents ample compensation for the site. For many years the tenant has been paying ground rent and there is a case for taking the site fine into account when assessing the purchase price of the land. There is also a case to be made for taking into account the number of years' rent paid by the lessee. This varies greatly from one tenant to another. The whole principle of buying out means paying the ground landlord in advance in perpetuity and it saves him the trouble of collecting the rent. There is a case to be made for having regard to these factors when assessing the purchase price.

A strong point can be made in favour of taking into account expenses incurred in providing amenities in an area where the general landlord has neglected to undertake such work. We are all aware of cases where estates have not been completed and money has been contributed by the lessees in order to make such amenities available. From the point of view of the purchaser, allowance should be made for this; likewise the failure of the lessor to make any demand for rent over a number of years. These are relevant matters in fixing the purchase price. We appeal to the Minister to accept our amendments or reasonable substitutes for them. There are aspects of the fixing of the purchase price which should not be ignored.

Speaker.P: I will deal briefly with the section which it is proposed to delete. I cannot see any logical reason for the inclusion of paragraph (g). Rarely can one come across a similar case where the person who disposes of property is responsible for the costs of the person who obtains the money. Taking the case of a person selling a shop, the person to whom he sells it would have to be responsible for the investment of the money paid to the shopkeeper. Such a situation would be ludicrous. There is no basis for it in law or in common sense. The basic yardstick is common sense. It is envisaged in the Bill that the tenant who buys out his ground rent must be responsible for the costs of the landlord in investing the money. If the landlord hires a stockbroker the section appears to provide that the tenant will be responsible for the broker's fees on behalf of the landlord. I cannot envisage this happening in any other line of business. The point is so clear that further elaboration is unnecessary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The proposal to delete paragraph (g) would have the effect that the arbitrator would not be required to take into account in determining the purchase price the costs and expenses of the landlord in investing the purchase money. The phrase “take into account” is an important part of that sentence. The new paragraphs proposed to be inserted would require the arbitrator to take into account various matters in favour of a reduced purchase price.

The first thing to be said about section 17 (2) is that it consists of a list of considerations which are only a guide to the arbitrator in drawing up the price. This list is not exhaustive. The arbitrator is enabled to have regard to such other matters as are in the opinion of the arbitrator relevant to the determination of the purchase price. Moreover, there are supervening general criteria such as the reference in the introduction of the subsection to what a willing purchaser would give and a willing vendor would accept and the operation of the maximum purchase price provision in subsection (3) which ensures that paragraph (g) of section 17 (2) cannot be relied on to justify an unfairly high purchase price.

MainHeading.P: It is fair to say that some of the matters to be inserted by the amendment are not really relevant to the determination of the proposed purchase price. For instance, a site fine, if any, paid by the tenant when he purchased the house is irrelevant in determining the value of the property being acquired. The property is the landlord's interest under that lease. Similarly, the question of how long the rent has been paid or whether it has been demanded is irrelevant. Anything that is relevant can be adduced in the arbitration. The criteria set out in section 17 (2) can be described as a package deal. Its purpose is to evaluate the actual interest being acquired. It is the same as what is in the 1967 Act and it should not be news to the House that this was also in the lapsed Bill which was introduced by the previous Government. I am quite satisfied that the package is fair to all parties and certainly has stood the test of time. It was based on the recommendation of the Ground Rents Commission and made. I might add, with full regard to the constitutional issues involved. If it were to be changed, in particular so as to tend significantly towards a lower purchase price, there is no doubt in my mind that it could be held to be confiscatory and would lead to constitutional problems.

In fairness to the case which Deputies O'Keeffe and Eileen Desmond made for the amendment, I accept that there is a lot in what they said in relation to paragraph (i), which deals with costs and expenses incurred by the lessee due to the failure of the lessor to maintain local amenities such as footpaths which the lessor had promised to do under the terms of the lease. I have great sympathy in this respect and I am in a position to accept that principle. I will not put forward a draft here and now, but in fairness to the case made I can accept the validity of the argument. I assure the House that if we went the whole distance this Bill might see the light of day as an Act but that is as far as it would go because of the constitutional issue.

Speaker.P: I am pleased to find that we have not been wasting our time on this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Deputies have not, and I assure them sincerely that I am open on it.

The amendment seemed meritorious to me. The Minister has relied on precedent and tradition for leaving paragraph (g) in the Bill and for not accepting our suggestion that it be deleted. I agree one must take into account that the paragraph could not be used to the outrageous extent I cited——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Perhaps I did not deal with this matter as well as I should have. The arbitrator may not go above the maximum purchase price and this is the rule that will be in operation in ordinary cases of dwellinghouses under subsection (3).
The question of the arbitrator would not arise if one were taking advantage of the automatic multiplier. The Minister is dealing with cases where the automatic multiplier would not arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Can the arbitrator not fix a price lower than the maximum?

He can, of course, but he must bear in mind the other matters in the subsection. We must make sure that what he must take into account will be fair. There is no question that he will take a lower figure than the maximum. If the automatic multiplier applied one would not be going to the arbitrator at all.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: If there is agreement it will not have to go to the arbitrator and if it goes to the arbitrator he will not have to fix the maximum price—he can fix a lower price, taking everything into consideration.

He can if the considerations which he is bound to take into account under the section lead him to decide on a lower price. A case would be going to the arbitrator only in default of agreement or in default of the householder being entitled to use the automatic multiplier—for instance, if there was less than a 25-year run on the lease or if the ground comprised 1º acres instead of one acre.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Would the Deputy accept that the maximum purchase price provision definitely sets a limit on outrageous claims for expenses, like the Chinese and South American treatments?
What is the maximum price the Minister is talking about?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Eight years' purchase.
That applies only if one is entitled to take advantage of subsection (3). If one goes to arbitration there is no entitlement to the advantages of the subsection.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Why not?

Because they are excluded. You are entitled to take advantage of subsection (3) if there is more than a 25-year run on the lease or if the ground does not exceed one acre in area. There would be no question of arbitration if one were entitled to take advantage of that clause, but if one has to go to arbitration because of not being able to take advantage of that clause the sky could be the limit because of the restrictions laid down in the Bill. The maximum price, of course, could not apply because the reversionary rent might be taken into account. Indeed it would have to be taken into account together with the other items listed. Deputy Enright quoted an example and so did Deputy Desmond, but they were not as outrageous as the one I cited. Is there any justification for putting such an imposition on the householder?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: Many factors have to be taken into account at arbitration. Everything must be looked at, considered, evaluated, so that the man who is doing the job can come to a decision.

We must remember that the arbitrator will have a quasi-judicial function and it will be his job to come to a decision based on the provisions of the Act. It is in that context that I put to the Minister the question of why the arbitrator should be bound to bear in mind in assessing the purchase money the expenses incurred by the landlord in reinvesting the proceeds. Nowadays it is entirely different. The amount of additional work in the Four Courts has caused considerable delays.

I visit the Land Registry quite frequently and the staff are as courteous and as efficient as one could find. To lumber this additional work on them will create a situation where there could be a complete breakdown in the system. I will give the House one example of the overcrowding in the Four Courts and it is no pleasure for me to have to say it in the House. I hope that it will not be taken out of context by anyone.

The taxpayers are paying for ten High Court judges but there are only eight courtrooms available in the Four Courts for those High Court judges. Occasionally the eighth judge has a second court available but the present situation is that one High Court judge has to say at home because there is no room available for him to hear cases in the Four Courts. The salary of a High Court judge is in the region of £12,000. It is beyond comprehension that the question of accommodation has not been remedied. It worries me to think that we will now have more people going down there.

If a High Court case is put down for trial to-day it is generally accepted that it will not be heard in 1978. The backlog of High Court cases in the Four Courts is so great that it takes from nine to 12 months for one to be heard. Because of that the Minister should have another look at this section because there is not sufficient room for registrars attached to the High Court in that building. There is no room to take on additional registrars for High Court judges. The fact that a High Court judge who is paid for out of public funds has nowhere to work is beyond my comprehension. We have now reached the stage where about 50 more people will be seeking accommodation in the Four Courts. It should be remembered that those 50 people will be seeking accommodation in a building where there is not sufficient room to conduct normal business.

If the Minister proceeds on this basis he will only have about 10 per cent of the cases through inside five years. He will be left with such a backlog that people will lose interest in trying to purchase their ground rent. The passing of this Bill presents the Minister with a glorious opportunity to continue with decentralisation. We have had forced decentralisation and we have had the decentralisation of sections of the Department of Lands to Castlebar and sections of the Department of Education to Athlone. In relation to this Bill staffs are available in all counties in county registrars' offices to deal with the cases that will arise. At present they deal with rent cases arising out of the 1967 Act. It is possible that it will be necessary to employ some additional staff but the employment of extra staff would be of benefit to the various towns.

One thing that annoys me about this Bill is that the people from Cork, Mayo or Donegal who have difficulties in relation to ground rent cases must travel to Dublin to the Registrar of Titles to explain their case. That is not good enough. I seriously question the wisdom of putting in such a provision. Those cases could be dealt with locally. The Minister may say that I am being political in raising this matter but that is not the case. I want the system to be fair to all people and I want it to work. I do not want to see more congestion in the Four Courts. I can assure the Minister that in five years' time he will tell me that I was correct. In proceeding in this manner the Minister is making the Act unworkable. I understand that in Cork every year 75 applications in relation to ground rents under the 1967 Act are heard. I am sure a similar situation exists throughout the country but those cases must now be heard in Dublin.

Speaker.P: The Deputy is connecting the position of the courts too much with this section and that is not relevant. We cannot discuss the position of the courts. The Deputy was dealing with conditions and space in the courts.

I was drawing the attention of the House to the fact that 75 applications are made annually to the county registrar in Cork under the 1967 Act and while it is working satisfactorily under that Act I do not think the same situation will apply when this Bill is passed.

I endorse what Deputy Enright has said. We are talking about changing from county registrars dealing with ground rents, as they have done under the 1967 Act and as it was proposed they would do under the National Coalition Bill, to their being dealt with by the Registrar of Titles. The Minister must know of the problems that exist in relation to the state of the Land Registry which, through no fault of the staff, is on the verge of a breakdown. The delays in the Land Registry at present are dreadful and it is very difficult to envisage how, because of its present difficulties, it can be the base to assist in a large-scale purchase of ground rents by householders. The work there is very heavy and increasing. The office is understaffed and the accommodation is totally inadequate, and that is the institution we are asking to implement this Bill. It is a vehicle with a very flat tyre. Its condition is so bad that merely replacing the tyres is not sufficient and I suggest we should replace the vehicle with the tried and trusted one of the county registrars' offices scattered throughout the country.

MainHeading.P: As a rural Deputy, I can clearly see the advantages of having the county registrar available to people in their own counties. Whatever we say about the simplicity of this Bill, I can say as a lawyer, having studied the Bill and amendments to it, it is not so simple. It is a very complex measure, as any Bill dealing with landlords and tenants is, and probably must be. We are on top of the Bill here today because we have studied it and we are in the white heat of discussion about it but the ordinary person will not be able to understand the ins and outs of it unless he puts a lot of study into it.

This is important to somebody in a rural area. Let us not make it political, the 1967 Bill was brought in by the Minister's own party predecessor and he provided that arbitration would be held before the local county registrar. The National Coalition Minister, Senator Cooney, was in fact extending the use of the county registrar rather than introducing a new concept. So, we are not being poltical in suggesting that the Minister should go back merely because it was a National Coalition Bill. Quite genuinely, as a rural Deputy I have no doubt that having the facilities available to people in their own counties will be far more convenient, far less expensive and will probably involve far more people availing of the facilities.

The question of decentralisation arises. People will have to be employed in relation to this measure. With the swelling numbers in this capital city every effort should be made to decentralise and have additional people employed in the country areas, in the other towns and cities, rather than add to the problems of an already overcrowded Dublin.

There is another major point I must ask the Minister to consider. I have had it looked into fairly extensively and obtained some advice on it. It is whether the whole question of having the Registrar of Titles deal with this part of the Bill and in particular with arbitrations under it is constitutional. I am quite serious about this. I am not raising any scares about it and I want the Minister to look into it very carefully. Section 21 (1), (2) and (3) provide for the appointment of the Registrar of Titles as arbitrator to determine (a) the legal rights of an applicant to require the fee simple, (b) the price to be paid by the applicant for that acquisition and (c) the vesting of the fee simple in the entitled applicant. Further, section 25—I am dealing with the whole question of the Registrar of Titles rather than the county registrar —provides that all the powers and duties under the Act of the Registrar of Titles may be exercised and performed by such of his officers as the Minister may authorise. That would imply that civil servants in the Department of Justice would be doing this or alternatively some people in the Land Registry. I am not sure what is involved but it certainly involves some people in a civil service capacity being authorised to deal with these applications.

I am raising a point on the constitutionality of the Registrar of Titles dealing with this part of the Act and particularly with arbitration. I do so bearing very much in mind that the question of constitutionality was raised when the 1967 Act was under discussion in this House as a 1965 Bill. The contributions that were made then are very relevant in the context of this discussion. At that time it was agreed on all sides that in fact the county registrar would, in carrying out arbitrations, be carrying out judicial functions, and it was maintained after much discussion that this would not cause any problem because the county registrar was a judicial officer. If that was the basis of the constitutionality of the county registrar carrying out arbitrations under the 1967 Act, is it now suggested that the Registrar of Titles is a judicial officer?

What is the position of the county registrar as opposed to the Registrar of Titles? The county registrar and his predecessor who was Clerk of the Crown and Peace was authorised by Acts of Parliament to carry out judicial and semi-judicial functions. He was a court officer as defined by the Court Officers Act, 1926 but the registrar of the Land Registry is not a court officer. He is appointed under the Registration of Titles Act. One must look at the qualifications for a county registrar. He must before appointment be somebody actually practising or who has previously practised as solicitor for not less than eight years. To be appointed Registrar of Titles I accept the candidate must have practised his profession for ten years but that period can include service in a civil service situation, so that in fact the Registrar of Titles may never have had any court practice. I imagine that he never had such practice—I am not quite certain; I am not talking of the individuals involved. I do not even know personally the present Registrar of Titles but under the terms of his appointment he need not necessarily have had any practice as solicitor or barrister. How then can this be a person capable of conducting arbitrations if he has never had any expertise in that field?

Going back to the type of work involved we must bear in mind that very complex issues can arise in these arbitrations. In this Bill we try to cover the ground as best we can but there are types of issues that the Minister possibly has not even considered, complex legal issues relating to whether the land is ancillary or subsidiary, whether buildings were improvements, whether buildings were erected in breach of covenant, whether buildings were erected by the person at the time entitled to the lessee's interest. At the moment oral evidence under the 1967 Act has to be taken in many cases from architects, engineers, surveyors, valuers and all types of experts. Inevitably, this has resulted in involved legal argument and interpretation of legal documents.

Generally then it seems that at the moment the right of the county registrar to conduct arbitrations under the 1967 Act is unchallenged; it is accepted that as a court officer he is constitutionally clearly entitled to carry out his functions under the 1967 Act and would be clearly entitled to carry out the functions under this Bill. What is the situation? The county registrar, as I know the working of it, has to carry out these functions in person, but we have a county registrar in every county and because of that the work-load is spread under the existing Act and he is able to carry out these functions in person. I cannot under any circumstances envisage that the Registrar of Titles, with all the work concentrated here in Dublin, would be able to carry out the work in person even if he were constitutionally entitled to do so. Section 25 provides that his powers can be delegated to somebody else without, apparently, any qualifications of any description. It states:
All or any of the powers and duties conferred or imposed on the Registrar of Titles by this Part may be exercised and performed by such of his officers as the Minister may authorise in that behalf.

I do not know if the word “his” relates to the officers of the Minister or the officers of the Registrar of Titles, but irrespective of that it would be to a civil servant directly under the Minister in his own Department or indirectly in the Land Registry. That person would be carrying out a judicial function if he is hearing arbitrations. I accept that other aspects would not involve judicial functions.

In the main I have to ask the Minister to give very serious consideration as to how this is going to be done and to consider whether it is constitutional to have the powers, particularly powers of arbitration, exercised by the Registrar of Titles.

Speaker.P: Is the Deputy discussing section 21 (2) which we have not come to yet?
We are discussing the question of whether powers should be exercised by the Registrar of Titles or the county registrar.
We are on amendment No. 12, section 20.
That is right.
The question which the Deputy seems to be labouring is in section 21 (2).
Many of the amendments relate to this point and we are discussing the whole question.
The Deputy may refer to all of them but I do not expect him to elaborate on them.

We are dealing with the question whether it is the county registrar in the area or the Registrar of Titles in Dublin who is going to deal with the matter. I have covered the ground but at this stage I am referring to the question of constitutionality, apart from the other points that have been raised in relation to the existing situation in the Land Registry, the principle of decentralisation and so forth. It is a very serious point and must have very serious consideration. Apart from the constitutionality of the situation, I suggest it is best to go back to the tried and tested way, to decentralise the work by giving it to the county registrar in the county in question rather than place the entire work on the Registrar of Titles in the Land Registry in Dublin.

I have listened to this debate with no rigid views as to whether the Registrar of Titles or the county registrar is the more appropriate for the purposes of the operation of this Bill. I am prepared to accept that the expert advice available to the Minister led him to the view that the Registrar of Titles was best fitted to deal with it. However, Deputy O'Keeffe and Deputy Enright raised very serious questions and they have brought their own professional expertise to make their case very forcibly in favour of the county registrar's office. I do not attempt to improve on that.

MainHeading.P: What I am concerned about is the additional staff which the Minister has told us he will make available. I hope that the facilities, the space and so on in the office of the Registrar of Titles will be such as to make for comfort and proper working facilities for the civil servants engaged in the operation of this provision in the Bill and that a proper service will be provided for the people availing of the terms of the Bill. In the past we have not had a good record of providing facilities for the work which increased legislation brings about. I am thinking now, for instance, in terms of recent legislation in the area of family law where facilities are still not available to ensure that the Act is operated as it should be. I want to ensure that we do not have a similar situation with regard to the operation of this Bill. Other Deputies have said that delays in the office of the Registrar of Titles have in the past been as long as three years. When I first came into public life we had three-year delays in that office with regard to ordinary dealings and I want to ensure that this will not happen again. Are we to take the Minister's word that he will increase the staff according to the needs of the volume of work created by this Bill? I would like to ensure that the facilities required for that staff will be made available to the office, and I would like to ensure that there will be no undue delay in so far as the proceedings of the applicants under this Bill are concerned. If the Minister will assure me of this I will be prepared to accept his view that the Registrar of Titles is the appropriate officer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. T. J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): As I understand this Bill, the object of it is to facilitate the purchase of ground rents by occupier-tenants and to simplify the legal machinery for vesting the ground landlord's interest in the occupying tenant. In my opinion the procedure under which the officer who will implement the legal procedure and vest the landlord's interest in the tenant is to be the Registrar of Titles in Dublin will not in any way simplify or cheapen the legal procedures involved. I ask the Minister to listen seriously to this side of the House on this topic. I am speaking as a person with considerable legal experience but I am also speaking as a rural Deputy familiar with country people and with very considerable experience of the capacity of country people to grasp legal problems and to explain them to legal men.

MainHeading.P: I say with all due respect to the Minister that, in the immortal words of a former Deputy of this House, the procedure to change over to the Registrar of Titles in Dublin is daft, and daft in the extreme. Instead of simplifying procedure it will complicate it. I believe that the Minister has in mind that the Registrar of Titles will take over from the solicitor and that it will no longer be necessary for the tenant who is buying out to instruct a solicitor and in that way he will save a fair amount of legal costs. I am convinced that the procedure which the Minister has adopted will make the employment of a solicitor absolutely essential. What the Minister is asking the tenant to do is to go up to Dublin, find out where Chancery Place is, go in to the Registrar of Titles, start talking to an individual he has never seen before, explain his business to him and transact his business in Dublin. That is simply not on.

Many country people rarely come to Dublin. Some of them come to Dublin only a few times in their lifetime. They find it difficult enough to find their way to Dublin but to put on them the burden of finding Chancery Place, going into the huge building where there are hundreds or even thousands of people employed, but still not half enough, and find out the section in the Land Registry which will deal with their business, make an appointment, stand in a queue, eventually find the Registrar of Titles or his deputy and start explaining and transacting their business with him, is not on. The Minister is going to drive the purchasing tenant into the office of a local solicitor. Maybe, as a solicitor, although I am not practising now, I should not be objecting to that but let us be clear and approach this thing in a common-sense way. What is going to happen? Is there any hope of somebody in Bunbeg, Blacklion, Newcastle West or some place in Cork, getting on a train or bus, getting his title deeds out of the bank or wherever they are and going to the Registrar of Titles in Dublin to do this job? There is not a hope of getting that job done the same day. He will go to the local solicitor, instruct him and this will not be cheapened one bit. If this was necessary I could understand it but it is not.

In every county town there is a land registry which contains the folios of every bit of registered property in that county. There is also a county registrar who invariably is a solicitor who has practised in that county, who is familiar with the type of people living there and has, perhaps, for over 20 years or more been dealing with them as a solicitor. He is there to perform many functions. Sometimes he is the probate registrar, he is invariably the local sheriff and he is the registrar of the Circuit Court. He does all this kind of work because it is his job. His office is usually situated in a central place in the county. I cannot understand why the Minister does not follow the precedent set by his Fianna F·il predecessor in 1967 and the National Coalition Minister when he more recently drafted the Bill, and leave this to the county registrar.

I do not believe this is the Minister's idea. I believe he is being advised by somebody or some group of people that this is the way to do it, for one reason or another. I am convinced that whoever is advising the Minister is not taking into account the convenience of the people of Ireland who will have to get this work done. They are not taking into account the expenditure that will be imposed on these people.

We are told that the fee will be £5 and £12. What is the return fare by train or bus from Cork to Dublin? Is there any guarantee that when a person comes from Cork or Donegal he will get his business done that day, that the person he wants to see will be available or that he will have all the information needed for that man? Is it not quite likely that the first trip to the great city of Dublin and Chancery Place will be in the form of a preliminary skirmish or investigation and the most he can expect to get that day will be a list of requirements? He returns to Cork or Donegal and sees his bank manager, the rent agent or somebody else and gets the rest of the information he needs. He then comes back to Dublin and as likely as not he will find that the officer dealing with his case is out sick, or is at his grandmother's funeral, or for some reason or another he is not available. If he hangs around the office until closing time he will miss the bus and will have to stay overnight in an hotel in Dublin, if he is familiar enough with the city to find an hotel. He might even spend the night walking around. That may sound funny but it would not be very amusing for the poor man who finds himself in this predicament. When you pursue this to its logical conclusion I concede that it becomes farcical.

If people from rural Ireland have an appointment to see a specialist in Dublin they are brought up in an ambulance. Why? First, because of the cost and, second, if they were left to their own devices it could take them two or three days to find the place they were looking for. This section is absurd in the extreme. I respectfully suggest that the Minister should not be so concerned about the convenience of officers who are well paid to do this business but should have more consideration for the ordinary plain people of rural Ireland who will have to avail of this service. The people of Dublin will not have to go to Cork, Cavan or Donegal. They will transact their business within a bus ride of the Land Registry while the rural people will be dragged up to Dublin. I am as certain as I can be of anything that the best way of making the legal profession indispensable in this business is to centralise it and to say that everything will be done in Dublin.

We all have experience of the Land Registry in Dublin. I do not find fault with the Registrar of Titles or his staff because they are doing their best but they are years in arrears. Even when country solicitors are dealing with the Land Registry delays can be interminable. Questions and queries can be raised and the business goes on and on, but for the ordinary layman to transact this business with the Land Registry in Dublin is daft in the extreme.

As Deputy Mrs. Desmond said there are delays there of three years. It takes a long time to get a map. I cannot give the exact times of the delays but people are coming to me in my capacity as a TD asking me to make representations to get things hurried up in the Land Registry.

I honestly believe that although the Government are paying lipservice to decentralisation there is some agency within the Government determined to centralise everything. I will give an example of this. We recently dealt with the European Elections Bill and argued it out for several days. The principal suggested amendment was to have a count in each county instead of centralising the entire count in one place in a huge constituency such as Munster, Connacht or Ulster, the last two in particular. The Minister for the Environment would not yield on that. He insisted that the count would take place in one huge centre rather than according to the method provided for presidential elections where the count is held in each county.

I believe—and I have good information on this—that already the Custom House has realised that the holding of two elections on the same day has become impossible. This is why the Taoiseach said yesterday that two elections should not be held on the same day. It is now realised that ballot papers would be mixed up, that there would be confusion and that someone might be defeated in a local election while two or three ballots in his favour might be 60 or 70 miles away. The Government would not accept our advice and we will be forced to have only one election on one day. I am asking the Minister to reconsider this. This is not a political matter; it is a matter of the convenience of people who will be availing of this Bill and whatever money will be saved by the procedures laid down in the Bill will be wasted on bus fares between Cork and Dublin and by overnight stays in Dublin and by the waste of the time of a tradesman or farmer or some other gainfully employed person. This procedure would not stand up to any serious consideration.

I would ask the Minister to tell us what virtue he sees in shifting the venue from provincial Ireland, from the county town where machinery exists, as it has done since 1898, to one big office in Dublin which is already overworked and understaffed and which has not sufficient space? I should like to hear the Minister's views.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I accept what Deputy Enright and Deputy Fitzpatrick and the other two Deputies said with regard to this being non-political. There is no question of politics in this. It is obvious from the approach of the four Deputies that we are poles apart in our thinking as to how best the Bill can be put into operation. Before I go into detail I would say to Deputy Enright regarding his comments on the Land Registry that I accept that it was understaffed. However, I provided a large number of staff at the first opportunity to deal with arrears of work. I have not the exact figure but a substantial number of additional staff were brought in by me shortly after I assumed office.

With regard to the additional staff required to do the work envisaged in this Bill, I have already said that sufficient staff will be made available. I appreciate that overcrowding exists in the Land Registry at present, but the additional staff who will implement this Act will have separate accommodation and this is being arranged.

Regarding comments by Deputy Enright in relation to the courts, High Court judges and so on, I recently had meetings with the President of the High Court and he did not tell me that because of lack of facilities any judge of the High Court had to go home and work there. I recently had meetings with the staff association representing registrars and neither did they tell me that they had not offices in which to work.
The Minister may take it as a fact that what I have stated is correct.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I am telling the House the situation as I see it. I have no doubt that Deputy Enright spoke in good faith. There is a certain shortage of accommodation and it is hoped that an additional courtroom will be available within six or eight weeks for High Court work. This should ease the situation somewhat, though I am not sure that the situation is as bad as Deputy Enright was led to believe.

MainHeading.P: I hope we do not give the wrong impression to the public at large that High Court judges earning £12,000 a year have no place to work and must go home. That would not be fair to the judiciary. I know the Deputy did not mean it in that way but one has a responsibility in talking about these things. I think there is a question on the Order Paper from Deputy O'Keeffe regarding this matter and we will go into it in more detail then.

I have dealt with staffing and accommodation. I might mention the output of work of those already in the Land Registry. I am presently trying to establish the additional work in the Land Registry as a result of representations by various people, including Members of the Oireachtas, to have cases dealt with speedily. I venture a guess at this stage—I deliberately use the word “guess”—that at least 25 per cent of the delay in the Land Registry is probably due to the fact that they are replying to and dealing with representations. When I have the result of that examination I will make it known to Deputy Fitzpatrick and the House. It was with this in mind that on Second Stage I spelled out clearly that there would not be any queue jumping as far as buying out ground rents is concerned, that they will be dealt with in order as they come in. There is a great deal of time being wasted because of queue jumping in land registration.

Deputy Enright referred to 75 cases dealt with in a particular year by the Cork County Registrar under the 1967 Act. The situation is that in the first two months after the commencement of that Act there were only 24 applications in Cork and in 1974 there were only 17. That is hard information.

Speaker.P: Has the figure gone up in the last few years?
I was dealing with 4 March 1977. In recent years there was an average of 75 Ground Rents Act applications per year. That is what the letter stated.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: What is the Deputy quoting from?
From relevant correspondence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I can find out the figures. It is only right to say that the case made by both parties opposite was extreme. Indeed I might say it was bordering on the ridiculous because of the examples given. It is not necessary for anybody to travel from west Kerry or west Donegal to Chancery Street. The price of a postage stamp is no different in those areas from what it is in Newbridge in County Kildare. I should like to remind Deputy Fitzpatrick and Deputy O'Keeffe that I am a rural Deputy and as much concerned with decentralisation as anybody. I replied to that argument on Second Stage. I am interested in any efforts to bring about decentralisation but that is an extremely delicate issue of more than ordinary concern. When the Bill was introduced by my predecessor, Senator Cooney, I said on Second Stage that I would doubt that using the county registrar's offices was the proper way to operate the scheme. I said I had grave reservations that they would be able to set up the necessary machinery. MainHeading.P: When I was replying to the Second Stage debate I got the impression that a number of Deputies did not appreciate that the use of county registrars' offices would require the availability of the county registrars' office staffs. Such staffs, general service personnel, are not legally qualified and indeed I understand that some county registrars' offices have very serious arrears of work. The task of examining title in a fee simple purchase or of acting as arbitrator is one for experienced and qualified personnel and in circumstances such as this it would be difficult, if at all possible, for large numbers of applications to be dealt with in county registrars' offices. Today it would not be easy to recruit qualified staff and even if it were possible to do so it would be grossly uneconomic. I believe the expertise and qualifications necessary to operate this Bill are all available in the Land Registry and I have already taken steps to provide additional staff to deal with applications under this scheme. There is no twisting my arm in regard to the operation of this scheme. I have said I am concerned about decentralisation but I am convinced the system provided for in the Bill is by far the best.

Speaker.P: The Minister has not dealt with the issue of constitutionality.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: I am sorry. With regard to that very important point, I have taken advice in regard to constitutionality and it is that we are not contravening the Constitution in any way. I double checked on that because of the importance of it.

I want to come back on a number of things. I have no doubt that there is a serious question of constitutionality involved here. It is not just the workings of the ordinary buying out. In relation to the arbitration section, an arbitrator is carrying out judicial functions. I believe that constitutionally an arbitrator must be a judicial officer. Section 25 deals with conferring powers, which can be performed by such of his officers as the Minister may authorise. I am not quite sure whether the “his” relates to the officers in the Land Registry or officers of the Minister and the Department of Justice. This could involve the messenger boy in the Department being authorised to carry out arbitration. That is an outrageous example.

MainHeading.P: I can tell the Minister that every arbitration under the 1967 Act has to be carried out personally by the county registrar. If there are to be 250,000 people, according to the Minister's estimate, using the benefits of this Bill there will be a substantial proportion of them who will have to arbitrate to secure their rights. It is not possible for the Registrar of Titles, a man already overworked in other areas, to personally carry out those arbitrations. We are then left with a situation that we are providing for a procedure which is physically impossible for the Registrar of Titles to carry out, and it is unconstitutional if it is carried out by somebody else. It may be unconstitutional to have a Registrar of Titles carrying out this function, because he is not a judicial officer. That would wipe out the whole arbitration section of the Bill.

Arising out of the question of dealing with arbitration—the Minister and his postage stamp and the £12 fee— the Minister seems to have overlooked the fact that in arbitration you have to produce evidence. If you have to produce evidence you must bring witnesses. As a west Cork man, I can tell him that it is far cheaper to bring witnesses into the city of Cork or to the local courthouse, to which the county registrar travels, rather than bringing architects, surveyors and valuers up to Dublin. The enormous cost involved in doing this is an additional imposition on the householder.

This is a further point in favour of having this power exercised by the county registrar in his own county. Under the 1967 Act the county registrar travels around to towns in his county. I have seen him travelling to the towns in my county and conducting arbitrations under the 1967 Act. I have appeared before him in arbitrations in the town of Skibbereen and I am aware that he has gone to arbitrations in many of the other towns in the county. I cannot envisage that the Registrar of Titles, with all his other duties, could physically cope with the job of going as a journeyman arbitrator all over the country. If he is constitutionally entitled to do this job, if the mountain does not come to Mohammed the reverse must apply. Additional expense is being put on the householder. This is an additional argument in favour of decentralisation. I feel very strongly about this section. The Minister is badly advised to centralise all those powers in the Land Registry and I strongly oppose this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. T. J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): Nothing could be clearer than that this proposal to centralise the administration of justice and the administration of this Act in Dublin is contrary to the whole trend in the administration of justice in this State for the last 40 years. After the establishment of the State appeals from the Circuit Court were heard in Dublin only. That was regarded as unsatisfactory. In the late thirties the procedure was changed and High Court judges and Supreme Court judges started to go out on circuit to every county town in Ireland and to hear circuit appeals there for the convenience of the litigants and the legal profession and in the interests of economy. That was a step in the right direction.

In the last ten to 15 years the High Court started moving out from the city of Dublin and sat in Limerick, Cork, Galway and several other venues throughout the State in the interests of the litigants involved and in the interest of economy. Up to a few years ago the court of the Land Commission, the lay commissioners, rarely sat outside Dublin. In the last few years the trend has been for them to go out and sit in practically every county town in Ireland where cases are to be heard for the convenience of the people. We have here a complete reversal of that policy and a return to Dublin.

MainHeading.P: The Minister talks about the difficulty involved in setting up machinery in the provincial towns to do this work. The machinery is already there, because in 99 per cent of the cases the local county registrar is also the district registrar of titles and has custody of the folios of every bit of registered land in his county. It may be that he will have to get more staff. In pursuance of the policy of bringing justice nearer to the man affected, the jurisdiction of the Circuit Court was increased in my time from something like £300 to £600 and from £600 to £2,000. I hear the Minister is talking about further increasing it in order that as many cases as possible may be heard in rural Ireland for the convenience of the people concerned. There is a complete change in this Bill.

I may have provoked a bit of amusement when I last spoke. However, although the incidents I gave may seem funny and may seem unreal, I am convinced the Minister will live to see the day, if this Act operates, that if people are to operate it without a solicitor they will come to Dublin to get their work done. There will be affidavits and deeds will have to be inspected. The people will come to Dublin, even when there is no arbitration. I am satisfied that the people will come to Dublin to see the person they are dealing with. If you come without an appointment the official may be busy and may not be able to see you. Anybody who has any experience of going to the Estate Duty Office or the Land Commission without an appointment knows that frequently the person one wants to see is not available. I am convinced that if this Act is to be operated without a solicitor it will be operated on a person to person basis, on an across the counter basis, between the client and the official dealing with it. But if there is arbitration, as Deputy O'Keeffe has quite rightly pointed out, and if there are arbitration provisions in this Act, how is the Registrar of Titles to arbitrate without the individuals concerned appearing before him and giving evidence?

This is the craziest thing ever. We are told that the Minister visualises something like 250,000 people involved in this. Did it strike the Minister that a big percentage of these will already be in the city of Dublin? The vast amount of ground rent transactions is already concentrated in Dublin. At any rate, one-third of the population of the country is within ten miles of Chancery Place. They will be all right because they are already in Dublin. I do not know what percentage. If the Minister says there are 250,000 people, I have no way to dispute that. However, I would say that a substantially bigger number will be already catered for in and around Dublin city. It is the people living 50 to 200 miles away from Dublin I am concerned about and the Minister, as a rural Deputy, should be concerned about. If we take the people who will be dealt with in Dublin and if we divide the remaining people by 25 or 26 we will not find that there will be an insurmountable task for the 25 or 26 county registrars throughout the country. If the Minister or his colleague or somebody is going to increase the jurisdiction of the Circuit Court substantially, further staff will be needed there anyway, and why not employ them full time?

The Minister has not provided an acceptable argument against this. He said that, having considered the structure available, he is satisfied that it would not work. The Minister's 250,000 does not hold water. There will have to be more staff in Dublin to deal with the people there, but the Minister must cater for the ordinary plain people who will have to travel long journeys from the four corners of this island to Dublin. The Minister, as a rural Deputy, knows as well as I do the country approach to matters like this. He knows full well that no number of postage stamps will get a case dealt with. No case will be dealt with except through personal contact across the counter. The Minister is making a provision whereby the city people, because they are only a few miles away, will be able to get their cases dealt with without a solicitor: they will be able to come into Chancery Place. They are more sophisticated and more accustomed to dealing with Dublin people, whereas the country people will be put to the expense of employing a solicitor or paying bus fares, train fares and hotel fares. There is no argument in favour of this. The sooner the Minister has second thoughts about this and lets common sense prevail, the better.

Speaker.P: In relation to what the Minister stated in reply to me, the number of High Court judges is ten and the number of courts available is eight. One of the judges normally sits in the Central Criminal Court as well, but there is one judge who has no accommodation. There are eight courts available for High Court judges in the Four Courts, four in the round hall court, five in the president's court, court six is beside the Supreme Court, and courts seven and eight are on the first floor in the Four Courts. This is not a criticism of the Judiciary, but I must criticise a system which permits a situation to arise where a judge of the High Court, who is being paid £12,000 a year, has no place to work. The sooner it is rectified the better.
I do not understand how accommodation for judges arises on this Bill.
It arises indirectly. The Minister said that separate accommodation had been arranged in Chancery Place for staff to carry out this new work.
It is all right in relation to staff, but it has nothing to do with the High Court or the Supreme Court.

Separate accommodation is to be provided in the Four Courts where already there is not enough room for existing staff. It is unwise to consider putting more people there at the moment. The Four Courts is overcrowded already. If 250,000 cases are to go through inside of five years, and if there are to be 40 or 50 extra people on the staff to work the system, the position in the Four Courts will become critical.

The Minister also stated that what we proposed in our amendments would mean the employment of additional staff in the county registrars' offices throughout the length and breadth of Ireland. That would be a good thing for employment in rural areas, instead of bringing people into a city already overloaded with people. We are almost through this Bill and we had no reason to vote on any matter up to now. However, this matter is so important that we cannot allow this section to pass without strongly opposing it on a vote.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan) Mr. T. J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan-Monaghan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan-Monaghan): The Minister has insisted that the officer to implement the legal proceedings under this Bill will be the Registrar of Titles, Chancery Place Dublin. I think the Minister is very wrong in doing that. It will lead to great inconvenience, very considerable expense and unnecessary journeys from far corners of this island to Dublin. I gave some examples on a previous occasion in regard to the cost of travelling—bus fares, for example, from Cork and Donegal, and overnight stays. The Minister seemed to think overnight stays would not be necessary.

May I gave an example of how country people can find themselves involved in unreasonable expense because they are not familiar with the city, do not know their way about and are not able to differentiate between one hotel or restaurant and another? Within the last couple of years I knew of a man and his wife who came to Dublin to see someone in a Government Department. They were simple people who rarely dined out. They were told in the Department to come back after lunch. The officer concerned would be back at half past two. They went out and looked around for a hotel or restaurant. They found one, went in and ordered a meal, which they enjoyed. When the bill came it amounted to £12. They were not familiar with the hotel and restaurant scene. Might I suggest that if the people who come up to Dublin to have this Bill implemented find themselves presented with a bill for £12 for lunch on even a few occasions the savings the Minister says he has written into the Bill will soon disappear and they would be better off with the old procedures rather than the promised one. This sort of nonsense could be avoided if the Minister would even reconsider between now and Report Stage his proposal to centralise all this in Dublin.
